overview: Dealing with disputes with neighbours - noise, statutory nuisances, high hedges, mediation and when your council can step in
title: How to resolve neighbour disputes

table.body:
Before making a formal complaint or getting others involved, try to discuss the problem with your neighbour. 

If you’re worried about approaching them, write a letter, explaining the problem clearly and sticking to the facts.

If the problem affects other neighbours, involve them as well. It can be easier to settle a dispute if the complaint comes from a number of people. 

A tenants’ association might help if you’re a member of one.

^[Get practical advice from Citizens Advice](http://www.adviceguide.org.uk/index/your_family/home_and_neighbourhood_index_ew/problems_where_you_live_index_ew/neighbour_disputes.htm "Neighbour disputes: Citizens Advice"){:rel="external"} to deal with common neighbour disputes, like high hedges.^
table.title: Talk to your neighbour

table.body:
If your neighbour is a tenant, you can complain to their landlord. This could be a [housing association,](http://portal.tenantservicesauthority.org/ "Find a housing association"){:rel="external"} the [council](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Find your local council"){:rel="external"} or a private landlord.

Landlords have an obligation to [deal with anti-social behaviour](/private-renting/antisocial-behaviour "Anti-social behaviour") by their tenants. If they don't fulfill this obligation, the council can take over management of their property.
table.title: Contact your neighbour's landlord

table.body:
If you can’t resolve the dispute by speaking to your neighbour, get help from a mediation service.

## How mediation works
Mediation is when an impartial person - trained in dealing with difficult discussions between two opposing sides - acts like a referee in a dispute.

There can be a fee for mediation, but this will still be cheaper than hiring a solicitor and taking legal action.

## Contact a mediation service

Mediation services differ depending on where you live:

+ if you live in England and Wales, find a mediation provider in your area on the [Ministry of Justice website](http://www.civilmediation.justice.gov.uk/ "Find a mediation provider in England and Wales"){:rel="external"}
+ in Scotland, use the [Scottish Mediation Network](http://www.scottishmediation.org.uk/ "Find a mediation provider in Scotland"){:rel="external"}
+ your [council](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Contact your local council"){:rel="external"} or [housing association](http://portal.tenantservicesauthority.org/ "Contact a housing association"){:rel="external"} may provide a mediation service
+ the charity [LawWorks](http://www.lawworks.org.uk/lw_mediation "LawWorks mediation"){:rel="external"} provides free mediation
table.title: Use a mediation service

table.body:
You can only involve your council in neighbour disputes under some circumstances. 

You should always try and solve the problem by talking to your neighbour or through mediation first.

## Statutory nuisances

If the problem with your neighbour is a statutory nuisance, [contact your local council,](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Contact your local council"){:rel="external"} which has a duty to investigate it.

A [statutory nuisance](http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/quality/noise/nuisance/ "Statutory nuisance: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs"){:rel="external"} is an activity that is, or is likely to be, damaging to health or a nuisance. Examples include:

- noise (including barking dogs)
- artificial light (except street lamps)
- dust, steam, smell or insects from business premises 
- smoke, fumes or gases
- a build-up of rubbish that could harm health

^ Complain to your council about a [noise nuisance](/report-noise-pollution-to-council "Report a noise nuisance to your council")^

## Boundaries and party walls

If the dispute is about boundaries or walls, contact your council's planning department.

^The Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) has free advice on [boundary disputes](http://www.rics.org/boundarydisputes "Boundary disputes advice: RICS"){:rel="external"} and [party walls](http://www.rics.org/partywalls "Party walls advice: RICS"){:rel="external"} (the walls you share with your neighbours).^

## High hedges and trees

If you're having a dispute about a high hedge, your council can only take action if the hedge is:

- 2 or more mostly evergreen or semi-evergreen trees or shrubs
- over 2 metres tall
- affecting your enjoyment of your home or garden because it’s too tall
- affecting your property

If you meet the criteria, ask your council for a [complaint form.](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Contact your local council"){:rel="external"} You might have to pay a fee.

$D
[Download information on high hedges from the Department for Communities and Local Government (PDF, 394KB).](http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/planningandbuilding/pdf/highhedgescomplaining.pdf "High hedges: Department for Communities and Local Government")
$D

### Your rights to trim hedges or trees
You can trim branches or roots that cross into your property up to the property boundary. If you do more than this, your neighbour could take you to court for damaging their property.

If you live in a conservation area, or the trees in the hedge are protected by a [‘tree preservation order’,](http://www.communities.gov.uk/publications/planningandbuilding/protectedtreesguide?view=Standard "Protected trees: Department for Communities and Local Government"){:rel="external"} you might need [your council’s permission](/apply-work-on-protected-tree "Apply to work on a tree that's protected") to trim them.

### Property damage from hedges
If a hedge damages your property, its owner may be liable for the damage.

You're responsible for maintaining your hedges so they don’t, for example, damage your neighbour’s property or grow too high.

*[RICS]: The Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors
table.title: Involve your local council

table.body:
You should call [the police](http://www.police.uk "Find your local policing team"){:rel="external"} if your neighbour:

+ is violent, threatening or abusive
+ is harassing you sexually, or because of your sexuality, religion or ethnic background
+ is breaching the peace (being disorderly in the street or making a lot of noise)
+ is breaking the law in any other way - or if you suspect this
table.title: Call the police

table.body:
If all else fails, you can take legal action against a neighbour. 

Taking someone to court can be expensive. There may be [court fees](/court-fees-what-they-are "Court fees - what they are") and you may have to pay a solicitor. You should see it as a last resort if other options don't work. 

##Legal advice
You can get free legal advice from a law centre, advice centre or [Citizens Advice.](http://www.adviceguide.org.uk/index/your_family/home_and_neighbourhood_index_ew/problems_where_you_live_index_ew/neighbour_disputes.htm "Advice on neighbour disputes: Citizens Advice"){:rel="external"}

The [Community Legal Advice directory](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/AdviserSearch.do "Community Legal Advice directory"){:rel="external"} gives details of all solicitors, advice agencies and information providers in England and Wales with the Community Legal Services (CLS) quality mark.

*[CLS]: Community Legal Services
